children.subject: I wish I could say I'm fine despite doing leetcode/61b level stuff feelsbadman
Honestly theres no list of classes to be completed, it totally depends on what you're trying to do. Just do some leetcode/61B level stuff and you'll be fine for 90% of interviews

history.content:
100 Leetcode problems + get referrals

-----------------------------

One major thing from my experience, interviewers are NOT looking for you to solve the problem 100% correct on the first try. They want to hear your thought process throughout the problem, so IMO it is much more important to think about general interview skills and communication. It is completely ok to ask questions and even work on the problem "with them" and ask for input. Don't waste your time doing hundreds and hundreds of leetcode problems, no company is looking for a robot that just happens to know how to do every single random coding problem there is. They are looking for people that can effectively communicate their thought process and ask for help when appropriate. Just for reference, for the offers I got this year I never solved one question "first try no problem." Frankly, I struggled with a good amount of them and ended up working back and forth with the interviewer as more of a pair programming exercise. Hopefully this will help direct your preparation efforts.

children.subject: This seems absolutely ridiculous. Me and many of my friends have been able to get big 4/big tech company internships from just 61b level knowledge.
Like I said, ymmv. Some people are quicker to learn than others, I was just giving my perception. Congrats on your offers though, hopefully one day I'll get there too.

Its not about quantity; if you're just solving leetcode problems like a robot, its not gonna be that helpful (unless you get lucky and see something you solved before). Its about first solidifying your basic concepts and understanding them in such depth that you can extrapolate them to unseen situations.

Yeah but my extrapolation skills aren't great so I gotta try more problems, and hence why I said, ymmv. Some people have better extrapolating ability than others. I was just giving my perspective on the numbers that I think should be decent enough for just about anyone irrespective of their extrapolating ability.
Yeah but solving lc problems isn't the only/best way to understand basic concepts in depth..
Also, just saying, if you worked so hard and still couldn't pass interviews, the problem lies somewhere else; its not not doing enough leetcode problems.

260 odd problems isn't really hard work, and I'm not surprised I didn't pass those interviews. All the questions I failed to convincingly get were from leetcode, it's just that I hadn't seen them or something real similar to them by the time I encountered them in the interviews. I just gotta put in some real effort over the summer, get to 600-700 whilst doing classes/ working on other stuff and I'll be fine. At least I know where the questions are from, so that's definitely a plus.

I wish Berkeley had some sort of decal or tech elective that helped you directly prepare for interviews, after you've taken 61B. 170 is unfortunately useless as currently formatted and there needs to be some kind of 170L which is entirely focussed on algorithmic coding rather than any kind of theory.

@Student response imo 100 leetcode problems is definitely not enough unless you were targeting one specific company and the questions that that company frequently asks. I think 400-500, with 50-100 easies, 50 or so hards and the rest mediums is a better safety net if you have never seen interview questions before. Of course it's a long process, so it'll take a few months to get there if you went at an average rate of 2 or so problems a day. But YMMV, since some people pick up a lot more information/intuition from solving one problem than others.

Personal reference point - Done about 270 first couple months of this semester and despite coming close in a few interviews, no internship. I know that not everybody needs to work equally as hard, and that I gotta work more than the average person since I'm unable to attain much intuition from simply doing 2-3 problems per topic/concept.

history.content: Is there an existing guide for the CS recruiting season? Like what classes should be completed, how best to prepare for interviews, and etc.
history.subject: Recruiting Guide?
